title: The Chinese Consulate General in Kuching donates 380,000 masks to various sectors of the Sarawak government (linked to project ID #96940, #96941)
description: In June 2021, the Chinese Consulate General in Kuching donated 380,000 masks to various sectors of the Sarawak government, including the Kuching Airport Immigration Bureau, Police Station, Fire and Rescue Bureau, charity organizations and other sectors of Sarawak. The staff of the Consulate General donated the masks directly.   This was part of a series of donations to various entities in Sarawak State, Malaysia, in June 2021. Other donations include 99,000 masks (30 boxes) to the Federation of Sarawak Chinese Associations (see project ID #96940) and a donation of 201,000 masks (67 boxes) to the Sarawak State Disaster Management Committee (see project ID #96941).
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
The Chinese Consulate General in Kuching donates 380,000 masks to various sectors of the Sarawak government (linked to project ID #96940, #96941)

# Description
In June 2021, the Chinese Consulate General in Kuching donated 380,000 masks to various sectors of the Sarawak government, including the Kuching Airport Immigration Bureau, Police Station, Fire and Rescue Bureau, charity organizations and other sectors of Sarawak. The staff of the Consulate General donated the masks directly.   This was part of a series of donations to various entities in Sarawak State, Malaysia, in June 2021. Other donations include 99,000 masks (30 boxes) to the Federation of Sarawak Chinese Associations (see project ID #96940) and a donation of 201,000 masks (67 boxes) to the Sarawak State Disaster Management Committee (see project ID #96941).
justification: Project involves donation of masks for public health purposes, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation of 380,000 masks to various government sectors and organizations for public health purposes

title: Chinese Consulate General in Kuching donates 48,000 masks to Sarawak Association of Ministers and Ladies (SABATI)
description: On March 22nd, 2021, the Chinese Consul General in Kuching, Cheng Guangzhong, and his wife, Professor Gao Cuilian, called on Juma Ani, the chairman of Sarawak Ladies Charity Institution (SABATI) and the wife of Sarawak Chief Minister Abang Johari. They handed over 48,000 masks, which SABATI distributed to less vulnerable groups in Malaysia.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:

# Description

They handed over 48,000 masks, which SABATI distributed to less vulnerable groups in Malaysia.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for social welfare purposes
evidence: Donation of 48,000 masks to support vulnerable groups, healthcare-related charitable activity

title: Chinese Government donates 100,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $1.8 million on March 25, 2021 (Linked to Project ID#95395, 95584)
description: The Chinese Government delivered 100,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Maldives on March 24, 2021 (as captured via Project ID#94774). The shipment arrived at Velana International Airport and was handed over on the next day (March 25, 2021). Chinese Ambassador to the Maldives Zhang Lizhong, Maldivian Foreign Minister Abdulla Shahid and Maldivian Minister of Health Ahmed Naseem participated in the handover ceremony. An additional batch of donated medical supplies for fighting COVID-19 was included in the handover ceremony (as captured via Project ID#95584).   Then, on March 30, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered another 100,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Maldives (as captured via Project ID#95395).    In July 2021, the Chinese Government pledge to donate another 400,000 doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Maldives (as captured via Project ID#95428). However, it is unclear if this pledge was ever fulfilled.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the March 24, 2021 donation as $1.8 million.2. The Maldives Food and Drug Authority provided Emergency Use Approval for the Sinopharm vaccine on March 14, 2021.
combined_text:

justification: Project involves donation of vaccines and medical supplies, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation of 100,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses and medical supplies for fighting COVID-19

title: China grants MVR 20,000,000 to the Maldives for the maintenance of the Sinamalé Bridge (linked to #38037)
description: In 2021, an unspecified Chinese government institution granted MVR 20,000,000 to the Maldives for the for the maintenance of the Sinamalé (Male-Hulhule) Bridge. According to the 2021 Budget in Statistics Handbook by the Ministry of Finance of the Maldives, a grant for 2023 will also be issued. The money went to the Ministry of Housing, Planning, and Infrastructure according to the budget report. The specifics of the grant are unknown.  This bridge was completed in 2018, and originally named the China-Maldives Friendship Bridge because much of its funding came from the Chinese government (see projects  #38082 and #38037 for more information). According to news reports, the CCCC Second Harbor Engineering Company is responsible for the maintenance of the bridge for seven years following its completion.
staff_comments: 1. The project was assigned the designation number P-BRG002-001 in the report.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China grants MVR 20,000,000 to the Maldives for the maintenance of the Sinamalé Bridge (linked to #38037)

# Description
In 2021, an unspecified Chinese government institution granted MVR 20,000,000 to the Maldives for the for the maintenance of the Sinamalé (Male-Hulhule) Bridge. According to the 2021 Budget in Statistics Handbook by the Ministry of Finance of the Maldives, a grant for 2023 will also be issued. The money went to the Ministry of Housing, Planning, and Infrastructure according to the budget report. The specifics of the grant are unknown.  This bridge was completed in 2018, and originally named the China-Maldives Friendship Bridge because much of its funding came from the Chinese government (see projects  #38082 and #38037 for more information). According to news reports, the CCCC Second Harbor Engineering Company is responsible for the maintenance of the bridge for seven years following its completion.
justification: Project focuses on maintenance of existing infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Maintenance of Sinamalé Bridge, general infrastructure focus, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments under multiple loans with the Government of the Maldives between January 2021 and June 2021 (Linked to Project ID#35020, #34996, and #38037)
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).  As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of the Maldives signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2021. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under multiple government concessional loan (GCL) agreements signed between 2010 and 2014: an RMB 455.6 million GCL for the China-Maldives Friendship Bridge Construction Project (captured via Project ID#38037), an RMB 982,500,000 GCL for Phase 2 of the 1,500 Housing Units Development Project (captured via Project ID#35020), and an RMB 481 million GCL for the 1,000 Unit Housing Development Project in Hulhumalé (captured via Project ID#34996). The total estimated suspension amount is RMB 68,467,299. However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of the Maldives. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments under multiple loans with the Government of the Maldives between January 2021 and June 2021 (Linked to Project ID#35020, #34996, and #38037)

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).  As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of the Maldives signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2021. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under multiple government concessional loan (GCL) agreements signed between 2010 and 2014: an RMB 455.6 million GCL for the China-Maldives Friendship Bridge Construction Project (captured via Project ID#38037), an RMB 982,500,000 GCL for Phase 2 of the 1,500 Housing Units Development Project (captured via Project ID#35020), and an RMB 481 million GCL for the 1,000 Unit Housing Development Project in Hulhumalé (captured via Project ID#34996). The total estimated suspension amount is RMB 68,467,299. However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt service suspension agreement is a financial arrangement without direct environmental impact or energy transition implications
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, financial terms, no direct project implementation

title: China donates COVID medical supplies to go with donation of 200k Sinopharm vaccines doses (linked to projects #94774, #95395)
description: On March 31, 2021, the Chinese Ambassador to the Maldives tweeted that medical supplies for fighting COVID-19 had been delivered the previous day, as part of a larger donation that also included two batches of 100k Sinopharm vaccines doses each (see #94774, #95395 for more information on each batch). The supplies appear to have been included in a handover ceremony held on March 25 for the first batch of vaccines. Chinese Ambassador to the Maldives, Zhang Lizhong, Maldivian Foreign Minister Abdulla Shahid and Maldivian Minister of Health Ahmed Naseem participated in the handover ceremony at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Maldives.    In the tweet, the supplies donated were listed as 201,600 disposable syringes; 1,500 boxes of nucleic acid coronavirus test kits with 25 tests in each box; 540 nucleic acid extraction kits with a note that one box would supply 60 people; 1 automated nucleic extractor; 10,000 N95 masks; and 5,000 protective suits.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates COVID medical supplies to go with donation of 200k Sinopharm vaccines doses (linked to projects #94774, #95395)

# Description
On March 31, 2021, the Chinese Ambassador to the Maldives tweeted that medical supplies for fighting COVID-19 had been delivered the previous day, as part of a larger donation that also included two batches of 100k Sinopharm vaccines doses each (see #94774, #95395 for more information on each batch). The supplies appear to have been included in a handover ceremony held on March 25 for the first batch of vaccines. Chinese Ambassador to the Maldives, Zhang Lizhong, Maldivian Foreign Minister Abdulla Shahid and Maldivian Minister of Health Ahmed Naseem participated in the handover ceremony at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Maldives.    In the tweet, the supplies donated were listed as 201,600 disposable syringes; 1,500 boxes of nucleic acid coronavirus test kits with 25 tests in each box; 540 nucleic acid extraction kits with a note that one box would supply 60 people; 1 automated nucleic extractor; 10,000 N95 masks; and 5,000 protective suits.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies and vaccines with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: COVID-19 medical supplies and vaccine doses, healthcare focus

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments under multiple government concessional loans with the Government of the Maldives between July and December 2021 (Linked to Project ID#35020, #34996, and #38037)
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).  As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of the Maldives signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2021. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021 under multiple government concessional loan (GCL) agreements signed between 2010 and 2014: an RMB 455.6 million GCL for the China-Maldives Friendship Bridge Construction Project (captured via Project ID#38037), an RMB 982,500,000 GCL for Phase 2 of the 1,500 Housing Units Development Project (captured via Project ID#35020), and an RMB 481 million GCL for the 1,000 Unit Housing Development Project in Hulhumalé (captured via Project ID#34996). The total estimated suspension amount is RMB 83,443,100.   At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).  As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of the Maldives signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2021. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under a $373.8 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement for the Velana International Airport Upgrade and Expansion Upgrade and Expansion Project (captured via Project ID#38083). The total estimated suspension amount is $3,403,170.   At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.   Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: The project involves debt service suspension and financial arrangements, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, financial terms and conditions, no mention of environmental or energy-related activities

staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of the Maldives. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0.

# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments under preferential buyer’s credit for Velana International Airport Upgrade and Expansion Upgrade and Expansion Project between July and December 2021 (Linked to Project ID#38083)

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).  As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of the Maldives signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2021. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021 under a $373.8 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement for the Velana International Airport Upgrade and Expansion Upgrade and Expansion Project (captured via Project ID#38083). The total estimated suspension amount is $3,372,270.   At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.   Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
